Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Engineering Meta-magnetic Shape Memory Alloys as the Future Generation of High Performance Magnetic Actuators

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award is to study the fundamental properties of meta-magnetic shape memory alloys (SMAs) to establish composition, microstructure and property relationship and to engineer the microstructure through thermo-mechanical treatments to result in magnetic actuators with high stress output. Meta-magnetic SMAs are a new class of smart materials where their actuation mechanism is based on field-induced phase transformation which results in one order of magnitude greater actuation strain than magnetostrictive materials and one order of magnitude higher actuation stress than well known NiMnGa magnetic SMAs, comparable to those of conventional SMAs. A deeper understanding of meta-magnetic SMA behavior will be gained by a systematic study of the effects of composition, crystal orientation, magneto-thermo-mechanical treatments and stress state on shape memory and magnetic properties including superelasticity, shape memory effect, transformation temperatures, hysteresis, Curie temperature, and saturation magnetization of transforming phases.

If successful, this research will enable the fabrication of a new generation of magnetic actuators at various scales that will provide an alternative to the existing solid-state actuator technology which in turn will benefit the economic development of our society. These actuators are expected to result in high actuation stress (>30 MPa/Tesla), high actuation strain (2-4%), and to operate at medium frequencies (<10 kHz) under low magnetic fields (< 2 Tesla). An integrated research and educational program will be built on strong foundations by bridging mechanics and materials science communities, through the use of smart materials in particular, to expose undergraduate students to multidisciplinary research early in their academic careers. Educating, empowering and exciting "front-line" middle and high school teachers by involving them in projects on smart materials through collaborations with well-established local outreach programs available at University of Kentucky will attract a large number of under-represented and economically-challenged students to pursue their future careers in engineering.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Smart materials are designed materials with one or more properties that can be significantly changed in a controlled fashion by external stimuli, such as stress, temperature, moisture, pH, electric or magnetic fields. Meta-magnetic sgape memory alloys (SMAs) are a novel class of smart materials comprising a new generation of energy harvesters, magnetic actuators, sensors, magnetocaloric materials, heat exchangers, dampers etc. Their actuation mechanism is based on field-induced phase transformation resulting in a one order of magnitude higher actuation strain than magnetostrictive materials and actuation stress than NiMnGa-based magnetic SMAs, comparable to those of conventional shape memory alloys, and projected response frequencies in the kilohertz (kHz) regime. In this study, the fundamental properties of meta-magnetic shape memory alloys were studied to establish composition, microstructure and property relationship. Moreover, their microstructure was tailored through the thermomechanical treatments, composition alteration and alloying to result in high stress for magnetic actuators. Lastly, the effects of orientation on their shape memory properties were revealed

The results of this research suggests that a new generation of magnetic actuators from textured meta-magnetic SMAs can be fabricated to provide a technological alternative to existing actuators with high actuation stress and strain that will benefit the economic development of society. They can produce stress of about 10 MPa/Tesla and strain of about 4% and operate at medium frequencies (<10 kHz). Orientation/texture, boron addition, composition and heat treatments can be utilized to decrease the hysteresis, improve ductility and strength, and control the transformation temperatures that would result in field induced phase transformation in these alloys. The design, discovery and growth of novel materials represent a national core competency that is essential for scientific progress and long-term economic growth. The magnetic shape memory alloys developed through this project can be used in a wide range of applications, from aerospace to energy industries. 

Undergraduate and high school students were exposed to research early in their academic careers and equipped with multidisciplinary knowledge.  Three undergraduate students involved in this research continued their career in graduate school. Graduate students had presented the scientific findings of this project at several international conferences and PIs had dismantled the project outcomes at workshops for K-12 science teachers, demonstrations to young kids and high school students, and summer programs for female high school students.  

 


Last Modified: 10/14/2016
Modified by: Haluk E Karaca

In this study, the fundamental properties of meta-magnetic shape memory alloys were studied to establish composition, microstructure and property relationship. Moreover, their microstructure was tailored through the thermomechanical treatments, composition alteration and alloying to result in high stress for magnetic actuators. Lastly, the effects of orientation on their shape memory properties were revealed The results of this research suggests that a new generation of magnetic actuators from textured meta-magnetic SMAs can be fabricated to provide a technological alternative to existing actuators with high actuation stress and strain that will benefit the economic development of society. They can produce stress of about 10 MPa/Tesla and strain of about 4% and operate at medium frequencies (<10 kHz). Orientation/texture, boron addition, composition and heat treatments can be utilized to decrease the hysteresis, improve ductility and strength, and control the transformation temperatures that would result in field induced phase transformation in these alloys. The design, discovery and growth of novel materials represent a national core competency that is essential for scientific progress and long-term economic growth. The magnetic shape memory alloys developed through this project can be used in a wide range of applications, from aerospace to energy industries. Undergraduate and high school students were exposed to research early in their academic careers and equipped with multidisciplinary knowledge. Three undergraduate students involved in this research continued their career in graduate school. Graduate students had presented the scientific findings of this project at several international conferences and PIs had dismantled the project outcomes at workshops for K-12 science teachers, demonstrations to young kids and high school students, and summer programs for female high school students.
